studyDesigns.name: Study Design
studyDesigns.rationale: Protocol-defined study design for investigating efficacy and safety

arms.name: LY900018
arms.description: Single 3-mg dose of LY900018 administered nasally.

arms.name: Intramuscular Glucagon (IMG)
arms.description: Single 1-mg dose of Intramuscular Glucagon (GlucaGen) administered via IM injection.

studyCohorts.name: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM)
studyCohorts.characteristic: Patients with a diagnosis of T1DM.

studyCohorts.name: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM)
studyCohorts.characteristic: Patients with a diagnosis of T2DM.

eligibilityCriteria.name: Current enrollment in other clinical trials
Recent participation in other clinical trials
Previous participation in this or other LY900018 studies
High total daily dose of insulin
History of severe hypoglycemia or loss of consciousness
History of epilepsy or seizure disorder

objectives.name: Primary Objective
objectives.text: To demonstrate that 3 mg LY900018 is non-inferior to 1 mg IMG for the proportion of patients achieving treatment success from insulin-induced hypoglycemia using a non-inferiority margin of 10%

objectives.name: Secondary Objective - Safety and Tolerability
objectives.text: To compare the safety and tolerability of 3 mg LY900018 with 1 mg IMG

objectives.name: Secondary Objective - Pharmacokinetics
objectives.text: To characterize the PK profile of 3 mg LY900018 compared to 1 mg IMG

objectives.name: Secondary Objective - Pharmacodynamics
objectives.text: To characterize the PD profile of 3 mg LY900018 compared to 1 mg IMG

endpoints.name: Primary Efficacy Endpoint
endpoints.text: The proportion of patients achieving treatment success defined as either an increase in PG to >70 mg/dL or an increase of >20 mg/dL from nadir within 30 minutes after administration of glucagon. The nadir is defined as the minimum PG value at the time of or within 10 minutes following glucagon administration.

endpoints.name: Safety and Tolerability Endpoints
endpoints.text: SAE, TEAEs (including gastrointestinal, nasal, and non-nasal AEs), vital signs

endpoints.name: Pharmacokinetic Endpoints
endpoints.text: PK parameters include AUC, Cmax, Tmax

endpoints.name: Pharmacodynamic Endpoints
endpoints.text: PD parameters include BGmax and Tmax

studyInterventions.name: LY900018
studyInterventions.description: Nasal glucagon (LY900018) is a powder formulation of human glucagon for the rescue treatment of hypoglycemia.

studyInterventions.name: GlucaGen
studyInterventions.description: Intramuscular glucagon (IMG) used as an active comparator.

studyInterventions.name: Human regular insulin
studyInterventions.description: Administered via IV infusion to induce hypoglycemia as part of the study procedure.

studyInterventions.name: IV glucose
studyInterventions.description: Administered if a patient has an insufficient response to glucagon administration.

activities.name: Informed Consent
activities.description: Informed Consent

activities.name: Randomization
activities.description: Randomization

activities.name: Admission to CRU
activities.description: Admission can be rescheduled if PG level is not 90 to 250 mg/dL on Day 1.

activities.name: Discharge from CRU
activities.description: Patient may be discharged 6 hours after glucagon administration. A patient may remain inpatient at the CRU at the discretion of the investigator.

activities.name: Medical History
activities.description: Medical History

activities.name: Collect Pre-existing Conditions and Adverse Events
activities.description: Collect Pre-existing Conditions and Adverse Events

activities.name: Physical Exam
activities.description: After screening, medical assessment only performed to include medical review and targeted examination, as appropriate.

activities.name: Height and Weight
activities.description: Height is at screening only. Weight on Day 1 will be collected before the start of the procedure to induce hypoglycemia.

activities.name: Collect Hypoglycemic Events
activities.description: Refer to Section 9.5.5.1.

activities.name: Collect Concomitant Medications
activities.description: Review patients insulin regimens to confirm acceptability to undergo the procedure to induce hypoglycemia.

activities.name: Meal
activities.description: After completion of all PK sampling, patients will be provided a carbohydrate-rich meal. The investigator will ensure the patients PG is stable. A prandial insulin dose will be administered if needed.

activities.name: Insulin infusion to Induce Hypoglycemia
activities.description: Procedures in Period 2 will occur at approximately the same time as those in Period 1. Insulin infusion is stopped once bedside PG is <60 mg/dL.

activities.name: Bedside PG Monitoring for Safety
activities.description: Samples will be collected during the hypoglycemia induction procedure and post study treatment (up to 120 mins). Bedside PG monitoring will be conducted no more than 10 minutes apart while bedside PG is 90 mg/dL and no more than 5 minutes apart when bedside PG is <90 mg/dL.

activities.name: Study Treatment Administration
activities.description: Once bedside PG reaches <60 mg/dL, the insulin infusion is stopped and approximately 5 minutes later study drug is administered. Indicates Time = 0 min.

activities.name: Injection-Site Assessment
activities.description: Injection-site assessment for IMG only.

activities.name: Nasal Inspection
activities.description: Nasal inspection both for IMG and LY900018.

activities.name: Vital Signs (Supine Blood Pressure, Pulse Rate, and Body Temperature)
activities.description: Time points may be added for each period if warranted and agreed upon between Lilly and the investigator. Predose time point will be between insulin infusion stop and study treatment.

activities.name: Single 12-lead ECG (Local)
activities.description: Single 12-lead ECG (Local)

activities.name: Triplicate 12-lead ECG (Central)
activities.description: Time points may be added for Period 1 and Period 2 if warranted and agreed upon between Lilly and the investigator. Predose time point will be between insulin infusion stop and study treatment.

activities.name: Clinical Serology Tests
activities.description: See Appendix 2, Clinical Laboratory Tests, for details.

activities.name: Clinical Lab Tests (Hematology, Clinical Chemistry, and Urinalysis)
activities.description: See Appendix 2, Clinical Laboratory Tests, for details. Patients do not need to fast for samples at screening or follow-up. At Periods 1 and 2, samples should be collected from patients who have fasted at least 8 hours before any study procedures.

activities.name: HbA1c
activities.description: See Appendix 2, Clinical Laboratory Tests, for details.

activities.name: Pregnancy Test (Female patients of childbearing potential only)
activities.description: Serum pregnancy test will be performed at screening. Urine pregnancy test will be performed at every admission period and follow-up visit if applicable.

activities.name: FSH (Female patients only)
activities.description: When needed to confirm postmenopausal status.

activities.name: Ethanol Testing
activities.description: Additional tests can be done at the discretion of the investigator.

activities.name: Urine Drug Screen
activities.description: Additional tests can be done at the discretion of the investigator.

activities.name: PK (Glucagon)
activities.description: Sampling times are relative to the time of study treatment administration (0 min). Predose time point will be between insulin infusion stop and study treatment.

activities.name: Plasma Glucose for PD
activities.description: -5 mins = stop insulin infusion. Sampling times are relative to the time of study treatment administration (0 min). Predose time point will be between insulin infusion stop and study treatment.

activities.name: Genetic Sample (Stored)
activities.description: Single sample for pharmacogenetic analysis taken prior to/on Period 1 Day -1.

activities.name: Anti-glucagon Antibodies
activities.description: In the event of drug hypersensitivity reactions (immediate or non-immediate), samples will be collected as close to event onset as possible, at event resolution, and 30 days following the event. Patients with TE ADA at follow-up/ED will undergo additional follow-up. Refer to Section 9.7.1 for details.

activities.name: Clarke Hypoglycemia Awareness Survey
activities.description: Clarke Hypoglycemia Awareness Survey

activities.name: Nasal and Non-nasal Score Questionnaire
activities.description: Sampling times are relative to the time of study treatment administration (0 min). Questionnaire will be collected in both LY900018 and IMG treatment groups in both periods.

activities.name: Edinburgh Hypoglycemia Scale: Experimental Hypoglycemia
activities.description: Sampling times are relative to the time of study treatment administration (0 min). During hypoglycemia induction will be when PG 75 mg/dL. Predose time point will be between insulin infusion stop and study treatment.

notes.text: Abbreviations: CRU = clinical research unit; ECG = electrocardiogram; ED = early discontinuation; FSH = follicle-stimulating hormone; HbA1c = hemoglobin A1c; IMG =intramuscular glucagon; min = minutes; PD = pharmacodynamics; PG = plasma glucose; PK = pharmacokinetics; TE ADA = treatment-emergent antidrug antibodies.

a. Samples for immunogenicity, should be collected every 12 weeks (847 days) until the titer returns to baseline (ie, returns to within a single 2-fold dilution of the baseline titer) or until 1 year after the last dose of study treatment. A time-matched PK (glucagon) sample may be collected at the follow-up immunogenicity assessment(s) if warranted and agreed upon between both the investigator and sponsor.

Note: If multiple procedures take place at the same time point, the following order of the procedure should be used: ECG, vital signs, and venipuncture. Plasma glucose sample should be collected as close as possible of protocol-specified time point.

{"id": "randomization_1", "ratio": "1:1", "method": "dynamic randomization", "centralRandomization": true, "sourceText": "I8R-JE-IGBJ(a) Clinical Pharmacology Protocol
Page 23
LY900018
5. Study Design
5.1.
Overall Design
This is a Phase 3, multicenter, randomized, open-label, active comparator, single-dose, 2-period, 
2-"}

titles.text: A Phase 3 Study of Nasal Glucagon (LY900018) Compared to Intramuscular Glucagon for Treatment of Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia in Japanese Patients with Diabetes Mellitus

indications.name: Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia
indications.description: Treatment of Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia in Japanese Patients with Diabetes Mellitus

study.name: A Phase 3 Study of Nasal Glucagon (LY900018) Compared to Intramuscular Glucagon for Treatment of Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia in Japanese Patients with Diabetes Mellitus

administrations.name: Human regular insulin infusion
administrations.dose: 2 mU/kg/min, adjustable up to 3 mU/kg/min for T1DM or 4 mU/kg/min for T2DM
administrations.duration: Until bedside plasma glucose level is <60 mg/dL

substances.name: glucagon
substances.description: Active ingredient in LY900018 and GlucaGen. A synthetic single-chain, 29-amino-acid polypeptide identical to human glucagon.

substances.name: human regular insulin
substances.description: Active ingredient used to induce hypoglycemia.

substances.name: glucose
substances.description: Active ingredient for rescue treatment of hypoglycemia.

narrativeContents.name: Study Governance, Regulatory and Ethical Considerations
narrativeContents.sectionTitle: Study Governance, Regulatory and Ethical Considerations

narrativeContents.name: Hepatic Monitoring Tests for Treatment-emergent Abnormality
narrativeContents.sectionTitle: Hepatic Monitoring Tests for Treatment-emergent Abnormality

narrativeContents.name: Protocol Amendment I8R-JE-IGBJ(a) Summary A Phase 3 Study of Nasal Glucagon (LY900018) Compared to Intramuscular Glucagon for Treatment of Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia in Japanese Patients with Diabetes Mellitus
narrativeContents.sectionTitle: Protocol Amendment I8R-JE-IGBJ(a) Summary A Phase 3 Study of Nasal Glucagon (LY900018) Compared to Intramuscular Glucagon for Treatment of Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia in Japanese Patients with Diabetes Mellitus

abbreviations.expandedText: area under the concentration versus time curve

studyDefinitionDocument.name: A Phase 3 Study of Nasal Glucagon (LY900018) Compared to Intramuscular Glucagon for Treatment of Insulin-induced Hypoglycemia in Japanese Patients with Diabetes Mellitus

studyAmendments.summary: The summary for this amendment is referenced in Appendix 9, which was not provided in the text.

procedures.name: Venipuncture
procedures.label: Blood Draw
procedures.description: Collection of venous blood for laboratory analysis, including pharmacokinetic (PK), pharmacodynamic (PD), hematology, clinical chemistry, serology, HbA1c, pregnancy, and FSH tests.

code.decode: Collection of venous blood by venipuncture

procedures.name: Urine Collection
procedures.label: Urine Sample
procedures.description: Collection of urine for urinalysis, pregnancy test, and drug screen.

procedures.name: Insulin Infusion to Induce Hypoglycemia
procedures.label: Insulin Infusion
procedures.description: Intravenous (IV) insulin infusion to induce a controlled state of hypoglycemia (plasma glucose <60 mg/dL).

procedures.name: Nasal Glucagon Administration
procedures.label: Nasal Glucagon
procedures.description: Administration of 3 mg LY900018 (nasal glucagon) powder for absorption through the nasal mucosa.

procedures.name: Intramuscular Glucagon Administration
procedures.label: IM Glucagon
procedures.description: Administration of 1 mg intramuscular glucagon (IMG) via injection.

procedures.name: Vital Signs Monitoring
procedures.label: Vital Signs
procedures.description: Measurement of supine blood pressure, pulse rate, and body temperature at specified time points.

procedures.name: Electrocardiogram
procedures.label: ECG
procedures.description: Recording of single and triplicate 12-lead ECGs to monitor cardiac electrical activity.

code.decode: Electrocardiogram, routine ECG with at least 12 leads; with interpretation and report

procedures.name: Bedside Plasma Glucose Monitoring
procedures.label: Bedside PG Monitoring
procedures.description: Frequent monitoring of plasma glucose levels at the bedside for safety during hypoglycemia induction and post-treatment.

procedures.name: Nasal Inspection
procedures.label: Nasal Inspection
procedures.description: Visual inspection of the nasal passages before and after study treatment administration.

procedures.name: Injection-Site Assessment
procedures.label: Injection-Site Assessment
procedures.description: Assessment of the injection site for patients receiving intramuscular glucagon (IMG).

procedures.name: Edinburgh Hypoglycemia Scale
procedures.label: Hypoglycemia Questionnaire
procedures.description: Administration of a questionnaire to evaluate the recovery from clinical symptoms of hypoglycemia.

procedures.name: Genetic Sample Collection
procedures.label: Genetic Sample
procedures.description: Collection of a single sample for pharmacogenetic analysis.

procedures.name: Height and Weight Measurement
procedures.label: Height and Weight
procedures.description: Measurement of patient's height at screening and weight at specified visits.

procedures.name: Intravenous Glucose Supplementation
procedures.label: IV Glucose
procedures.description: Administration of intravenous (IV) glucose if the patient experiences signs and symptoms of severe hypoglycemia requiring intervention.

medicalDevices.name: Nasal Dosing Device
medicalDevices.label: Nasal Glucagon Device
medicalDevices.description: A user-friendly, single-use, nasal dosing device that delivers 3 mg glucagon powder (LY900018).

medicalDevices.name: Syringe and Needle
medicalDevices.label: Syringe/Needle
medicalDevices.description: Device used for intramuscular (IM) injection of reconstituted glucagon powder.

medicalDevices.name: IV Infusion System
medicalDevices.label: IV Infusion
medicalDevices.description: System used for the intravenous (IV) infusion of insulin to induce hypoglycemia and for potential administration of rescue glucose.

medicalDevices.name: 12-lead ECG Machine
medicalDevices.label: ECG Machine
medicalDevices.description: Device used to perform single and triplicate 12-lead electrocardiograms.

medicalDevices.name: Continuous Subcutaneous Insulin Infusion Pump
medicalDevices.label: CSII Pump
medicalDevices.description: An insulin pump used by some patients for their daily insulin therapy.

timings.name: Maximum Duration of Additional Follow-up for TE ADA
Study Drug Administration after Insulin Stop

conditions.name: Admission Criteria for Day 1
conditions.description: Plasma Glucose level required for admission on Day 1 of a treatment period.
conditions.text: PG level must be 90 to 250 mg/dL on Day 1.

conditions.name: Insulin Infusion Stop Criteria
conditions.description: Condition to stop the insulin infusion to induce hypoglycemia.

conditions.name: Additional Follow-up Trigger
conditions.description: Condition for entering the additional follow-up phase for immunogenicity.
conditions.text: Patient has treatment-emergent antidrug antibodies (TE ADA) at the follow-up/early discontinuation visit.

conditions.name: Interim Safety Review Condition for Continuation
conditions.description: Condition for continuing dosing after the first 6 patients complete Period 2.
conditions.text: No clinically significant safety findings for treatment or study procedure are noted after the first 6 patients complete Period 2 Day 1.

conditions.name: Inadvertent Enrollment
conditions.description: Condition where a patient did not meet enrollment criteria.
conditions.text: The sponsor or investigator identifies a patient who did not meet enrollment criteria and was inadvertently enrolled.

conditions.name: Study Termination Condition
conditions.description: Condition for stopping the entire study based on interim safety review.
conditions.text: Study will be stopped if deemed necessary for patient safety in the opinion of the Investigator and sponsor following the review of the safety data from the first 6 patients to complete Period 2 Day 1.

transitionRules.name: Transition to Additional Follow-up
transitionRules.text: Triggered by positive TE ADA test at follow-up/ED visit.

transitionRules.name: End of Additional Follow-up
transitionRules.text: Additional follow-up for TE ADA ends when titer returns to baseline or 1 year after the last dose, whichever comes first.

transitionRules.name: Discontinuation for Inadvertent Enrollment
transitionRules.text: Patients inadvertently enrolled may be discontinued. However, they may continue if deemed medically appropriate and approved by the sponsor.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Discontinuation due to Other Study Participation
scheduleTimelineExits.description: Patient is discontinued for enrollment in any other clinical study involving an investigational product or other incompatible medical research.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Discontinuation for Medical/Safety/Regulatory Reasons
scheduleTimelineExits.description: Discontinuation because participation needs to be stopped for medical, safety, regulatory, or other reasons consistent with applicable laws, regulations, and good clinical practice.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Discontinuation by Investigator Decision
scheduleTimelineExits.description: The investigator decides that the patient should be discontinued from the study for any reason.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Discontinuation by Patient Withdrawal
scheduleTimelineExits.description: The patient, or legal representative, requests to be withdrawn from the study.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Study Termination for Safety
scheduleTimelineExits.description: The entire study may be stopped for patient safety reasons after an interim review of the first 6 patients completing Period 2.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Lost to Follow-up
scheduleTimelineExits.description: Patient is considered lost to follow-up if he or she repeatedly fails to return for scheduled visits and is unable to be contacted by the study site.

scheduleTimelineExits.name: Study Completion
scheduleTimelineExits.description: Patient has completed both treatment periods and the final follow-up visit.

analysisPopulations.name: All Entered Set Population
analysisPopulations.label: AES
analysisPopulations.description: All patients who sign inform consent and enter in this study
analysisPopulations.criteria: Signed informed consent and entered the study

analysisPopulations.name: All Randomized Set Population
analysisPopulations.label: ARS
analysisPopulations.description: All patients who are randomized to study treatments

analysisPopulations.name: Full Analysis Set Population
analysisPopulations.label: FAS
analysisPopulations.description: All randomized patients who receive at least 1 dose of study drug
analysisPopulations.criteria: Randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug

analysisPopulations.name: Efficacy Analysis Set Population
analysisPopulations.label: EAS
analysisPopulations.description: Patients in the FAS and have evaluable primary efficacy outcome
analysisPopulations.criteria: Member of the Full Analysis Set (FAS) with an evaluable primary efficacy outcome

analysisPopulations.name: PK/PD Population
analysisPopulations.label: PK/PD
analysisPopulations.description: Patients in the FAS and have evaluable PK/PD.
analysisPopulations.criteria: Member of the Full Analysis Set (FAS) with evaluable Pharmacokinetic (PK) and Pharmacodynamic (PD) data

analysisPopulations.name: Safety Analysis Set
analysisPopulations.label: FAS
analysisPopulations.description: All randomized patients who receive at least 1 dose of study drug. Per the SAP, all safety analyses will be conducted on data from the FAS.
analysisPopulations.criteria: Randomized and received at least 1 dose of study drug

commentAnnotations.text: Note to Regulatory Authorities: This document may contain protected personal data and/or commercially confidential information exempt from public disclosure. Eli Lilly and Company requests consultation regarding release/redaction prior to any public release. In the United States, this document is subject to Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Exemption 4 and may not be reproduced or otherwise disseminated without the written approval of Eli Lilly and Company or its subsidiaries.
At Periods 1 and 2, samples should be collected from patients who have fasted at least 8 hours before any study procedures.
If a patient sneezes immediately after administration, document using the Nasal and Non-nasal Score Questionnaire (see Appendix 6 for a copy of the questionnaire).
if an SAE occurs after signing informed consent, but prior to receiving investigational product, AND is considered reasonably possibly related to a study procedure then it MUST be reported.

Pregnancy (maternal or paternal exposure to investigational product) does not meet the definition of an AE. However, to fulfill regulatory requirements any pregnancy should be reported following the SAE process to collect data on the outcome for both mother and fetus.

Only severe hypoglycemic episodes will be reported separately as AEs. If a hypoglycemic event meets the criteria of severe, it needs to be recorded as serious in the CRF (that is, recorded as an SAE).

studyDefinitionDocumentVersions.description: Protocol Amendment (a) approved on 05-Dec-2017. Base protocol approved on 26-Oct-2017.
